editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To all my fellow Creatures that shall view the≈øe en≈øuing Lines.
div.p: THE God of this world blinding the eyes of the men of the world, have taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them and their Lives, Rules and Raigns, and in a high mea≈øure oppo≈øeth the everla≈øting ≈øpirit, the King of Righteou≈øne≈øs; both in them, and on the whole Creation, bending all its wit and power to de≈øtroy this ≈øpirit, and the per≈øons in whom it lives, rules and governs; making Lawes under ≈øpecious pretences, yea and penalties too, that all Nations, Tongues, and Languages, ≈øhall fall down and wor≈øhip this god, become ≈øubject, yea in ≈ølavery to it, and to the men in whom it dwels: But the god of this world is Pride and Covetou≈øne≈øs, the rootes of all Evil, from whence flowes all the wickedne≈øs that is acted under the Sun, as Malice, Tyranny, Lording over, and de≈øpi≈øing their fellow Creatures, killing and de≈øtroying tho≈øe that will not, or cannot become ≈øubject to their Tyranny, to uphold their Lordly Power, Pride, and Covetou≈øne≈øs.

I have had ≈øome Conver≈øation with the Author of this en≈øuing Declaration, and the Per≈øons Sub≈øcribing, and by experience find them ≈øweetly acted and guided by the everla≈øting ≈øpirit, the Prince of Peace, to walk in the paths of Righteou≈øne≈øs, not daring to venture upon any acts of inju≈øtice; but endeavouring to do unto all, as they would have done to them, having Peace and Joy in them≈øelves, knit together and united in one Spirit of Glory and Truth, Love to their fellow Creatures, Contentation with Food
and Rayment, ≈øhewing much Humility and Meekne≈øs of ≈øpirit; ≈øuch as the≈øe ≈øhall be partakers of the Promi≈øe.

div.p: Secondly, For this action of theirs, in labouring to Manure the wa≈øt places of the Earth, it is an action full of Iu≈øtice and Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, full of Love and Charity to their fellow Creatures; nothing of the god of this world, Pride and Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øeen in it, no ≈øelf-≈øeeking, or glorying in the Fle≈øh.

Vouch≈øafe to reade, or view over the≈øe en≈øuing Lines yee Powers of the Earth; Oh that Rea≈øon might ≈øit upon the throne of your hearts as Iudge; I am confident there is nothing written in anger or hatred to your per≈øons, but in love to them as fellow Creatures; but again≈øt that which have bound up your own Spirits in ≈ølavery; if you could ≈øpeak impartially, your own Con≈øciences can bear me witne≈ø≈øe, and only bears ≈øway in your forcing you to exerci≈øe Tyranny, ≈øcourging and trampling under foot your fellow Creatures, e≈øpecially tho≈øe who≈øe eyes are opened and can cleerly di≈øcover the great Devil, Tyranny, Pride, and Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe working to and fro upon your Spirits, and raigning in you, which will prove your own de≈øtruction: The Angels that kept not their fir≈øt E≈øtate, are re≈øerved under Chains of darkne≈ø≈øe unto the Iudgment of the great day.

The whole Creation are the Angels of the everla≈øting Spirit of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, they are all mini≈øtring ≈øpirits, ≈øpeaking every Creature in its kind the Will of the Father. The Chariots of God are 20000 thou≈øands of Angels, P≈øal. &c.

But yee the great ones of the Earth, the Powers of this world, yee are the Angels that kept not your fir≈øt e≈øtate, and now remain under Chains of darkne≈ø≈øe: Your fir≈øt E≈øtate was Innocency and Equallity with your fellow Creatures, but your Lordly power over them, both Per≈øons and Con≈øciences, your proud fle≈øhly imaginations, lofty thoughts of your ≈øelves, are the fruits of darkne≈ø≈øe which you are kept under: The whole Creation groaneth and is in bondage, even until now, waiting for deliverance, and mu≈øt wait till he that with-holdeth be taken away, that man of ≈øin, that Antichri≈øt which ≈øits in the throne, in the hearts of the men of this world, the Powers of the Earth, above all that is call ‚Ä¢ d God.

I know you have high thoughts of your ≈øelves, think you know much, and ≈øee much, but the Light that is in you is Darkne≈ø≈øe; and how great is that darkne≈ø≈øe? They that live in the light of the Spirit can di≈øcover that to be the blackne≈ø≈øe of darkne≈ø≈øe which you count light. And truly, a great Light, a bright Morning Star which will flouri≈øh and ≈øpread it ≈øelf, ≈øhining in Darkne≈ø≈øe, and darkne≈ø≈øe ≈øhall not be able to comprehend it, though you Spurn never ≈øo much again≈øt it.

I expect nothing but oppo≈øition, mockings, deridings from Lord E≈øau the man of Fle≈øh: I know it will be counted in the eye of Fle≈øh, a fooli≈øh undertaking, an object of ≈øcorn and laughter; but in this is their Comfort and incouragement, That the power of Life and Light, the Spirit by whom they are commanded, will carry them on, ≈øtrengthen and ≈øupport them, re≈øcuing them from the Jaw of the Lyon and Paw of the Bear; For great is the work which will ≈øhortly be done upon the Earth. De≈øpi≈øe not Vi≈øions, Voyces and Revelations; examine the Scriptures, Prophe≈øies are now fulfilling; be not like Jo≈øephs Brethren, ≈øpeak not evil of things you know not: For what≈øoever is of God will ≈øtand, do what you can, though you may cru≈øh it for a time, the time is neer expired it will spring up again and flouri≈øh like a green Bay tree: What is not of the Father will fall to the ground, though you bend all your wit, power and policy to keep it up; but of that will be no Re≈øurrection. That the eternal Spirit may enlighten you, that Rea≈øon may dwel in you, and act accordingly, is the de≈øire of your Loving Friend, and Fellow Creature,

div.head: A Declaration to the Powers of England, and to all the Powers of the World, Shewing the Cau≈øe why the Common People of England have begun, and gives Con≈øent to Digge up, Manure, and Sowe Corn upon George-Hill in Surrey; by tho≈øe that have Sub≈øcribed, and thou≈øands more that gives Con≈øent.
div.p: IN the beginning of Time, the great Creator Rea≈øon, made the Earth to be a Common Trea≈øury, to pre≈øerve Bea≈øts, Birds, Fi≈øhes, and Man, the lord that was to govern this Creation; for Man had Domination given to him, over the Bea≈øts, Birds, and Fi≈øhes; but not one word was ≈øpoken in the beginning, That one branch of mankind ≈øhould rule over another.

And the Rea≈øon is this, Every ≈øingle man, Male and Female, is a perfect Creature of him≈øelf; and the ≈øame Spirit that made the Globe, dwels in man to govern the Globe; ≈øo that the fle≈øh of man being ≈øubject to Rea≈øon, his Maker, hath him to be his Teacher and Ruler within him≈øelf, therefore needs not run abroad after any Teacher and Ruler without him, for he needs not that any man ≈øhould teach him, for the ≈øame Anoynting that ruled in the Son of man, teacheth him all things.

But ≈øince humane fle≈øh (that king of Bea≈øts) began to delight him≈øelf in the objects of the Creation, more then in the Spirit Rea≈øon and Righteou≈øne≈øs, who manife≈øts him≈øelf to be the indweller in the Five Sences, of Hearing, Seeing, Ta≈øting, Smelling, Feeling; then he fell into blindne≈øs of mind and weakne≈øs of heart, and runs abroad for a Teacher and Ruler: And ≈øo ≈øelfi≈øh imaginations taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Five Sences, and ruling as King in the room of Rea≈øon therein, and working with Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe,
did ≈øet up one man to teach and rule over another; and thereby the Spirit was killed, and man was brought into bondage, and became a greater Slave to ≈øuch of his own kind, then the Bea≈øts of the field were to him.

And hereupon, The Earth (which was made to be a Common Trea≈øury of relief for all, both Bea≈øts and Men) was hedged in to In-clo≈øures by the teachers and rulers, and the others were made Servants and Slaves: And that Earth that is within this Creation made a Common Store-hou≈øe for all, is bought and ≈øold, and kept in the hands of a few, whereby the great Creator is mightily di≈øhonored, as if he were a re≈øpector of per≈øons, delighting in the comfortable Livelihood of ≈øome, and rejoycing in the mi≈øerable povertie and ≈øtraits of others. From the beginning it was not ≈øo.

But this coming in of Bondage, is called A-dam, becau≈øe this ruling and teaching power without, doth dam up the Spirit of Peace and Liberty; Fir≈øt within the heart, by filling it with ≈ølavi≈øh fears of others. Secondly without, by giving the bodies of one to be impri≈øoned, puni≈øhed and oppre≈ø≈øed by the outward power of another. And this evil was brought upon us through his own Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, whereby he is blinded and made weak, and ≈øees not the Law of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe in his heart, which is the pure light of Rea≈øon, but looks abroad for it, and thereby the Creation is ca≈øt under bondage and cur≈øe, and the Creator is ≈øleighted; Fir≈øt by the Teachers and Rulers that ≈øets them≈øelves down in the Spirits room, to teach and rule, where he him≈øelf is only King. Secondly by the other, that refu≈øes the Spirit, to be taught and governed by fellow Creatures, and this was called I≈øraels Sin, in ca≈øting off the Lord, and chu≈øing Saul, one like them≈øelves to be their King, when as they had the ≈øame Spirit of Rea≈øon and government in them≈øelves, as he had, if they were but ≈øubject. And I≈øraels rejecting of outward teachers and rulers to embrace the Lord, and to be all taught and ruled by that righteous King, that Jeremiah Prophe≈øied ≈øhall rule in the new Heavens and new Earth in the latter dayes, will be their Re≈øtauration from bondage, Ier. 23.5, 6.

But for the pre≈øent ≈øtate of the old World that is running up like parchment in the fire, and wearing away, we ≈øee proud Imaginary
fle≈øh, which is the wi≈øe Serpent, ri≈øes up in fle≈øh and gets dominion in ≈øome to rule over others, and ≈øo forces one part of the Creation man, to be a ≈ølave to another; and thereby the Spirit is killed in both. The one looks upon him≈øelf as a teacher and ruler, and ≈øo is lifted up in pride over his fellow Creature: The other looks upon him≈øelf as imperfect, and ≈øo is dejected in his Spirit, and looks upon his fellow Creature of his own Image, as a Lord above him.

And thus E≈øau, the man of fle≈øh, which is Covetou≈øne≈øs and Pride, hath killed Jacob, the Spirit of meekne≈ø≈øe, and righteous government in the light of Rea≈øon, and rules over him: And ≈øo the Earth that was made a common Trea≈øury for all to live comfortably upon, is become through mans unrighteous actions one over another, to be a place, wherein one torments another.

Now the great Creator, who is the Spirit Rea≈øon, ≈øuffered him≈øelf thus to be rejected, and troden under foot by the covetous proud fle≈øh, for a certain time limited; therefore ≈øaith he, The Seed out of whom the Creation did proceed, which is my Self, ≈øhall brui≈øe this Serpents head, and re≈øtore my Creation again from this cur≈øe and bondage; and when I the King of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe raigns in every man, I will be the ble≈ø≈øing of the Earth, and the joy of all Nations.

And ≈øince the coming in of the ≈øtoppage, or the A-dam the Earth hath been inclo≈øed and given to the Elder brother E≈øau, or man of fle≈øh, and hath been bought and ≈øold from one to another; and Iacob, or the yonger brother, that is to ≈øucceed or come forth next, who is the univer≈øal ≈øpreading power of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe that gives liberty to the whole Creation, is made a ≈øervant.

And this Elder Son, or man of bondage, hath held the Earth in bondage to him≈øelf, not by a meek Law of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, But by ≈øubtle ≈øelfi≈øh Councels, and by open and violent force; for wherefore is it that there is ≈øuch Wars and rumours of Wars in the Nations of the Earth? and wherefore are men ≈øo mad to de≈øtroy one another? But only to uphold Civil propriety of Honor, Dominion and Riches one over another, which is the cur≈øe the Creation groans under, waiting for deliverance.

But when once the Earth becomes a Common Trea≈øury again, as it mu≈øt, for all the Prophe≈øies of Scriptures and Rea≈øon are Circled here in this Community, and mankind mu≈øt have the Law of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe once more writ in his heart, and all mu≈øt be made of one heart, and one mind.

Then this Enmity in all Lands will cea≈øe, for none ≈øhall dare to ≈øeek a Dominion over others, neither ≈øhall any dare to kill another, nor de≈øire more of the Earth then another; for he that will rule over, impri≈øon, oppre≈ø≈øe, and kill his fellow Creatures, under what pretence ≈øoever, is a de≈øtroyer of the Creation, and an actor of the Cur≈øe, and walks contrary to the rule of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe: (Do, as you would have others do to you; and love your Enemies, not in Words, but in actions).

Therefore you powers of the Earth, or Lord E≈øau, the Elder brother, becau≈øe you have appeared to rule the Creation, fir≈øt take notice, That the power that ≈øets you to work, is ≈øelvi≈øh Covetou≈ønes, and an a≈øpiring Pride, to live in glory and ea≈øe over Iacob, the meek Spirit; that is, the Seed that lies hid, in & among the poor Common People, or yonger Brother, out of whom the ble≈ø≈øing of Deliverance is to ri≈øe and ≈øpring up to all Nations.

And Rea≈øon, the living king of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, doth only look on, and lets thee alone, That whereas thou counts thy ≈øelf an Angel of Light, thou ≈øhalt appear in the light of the Sun, to be a Devil, A-dam, and the Cur≈øe that the Creation groans under; and the time is now come for thy downfal, and Iacob mu≈øt ri≈øe, who is the univer≈øal Spirit of love and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, that fils, and will fill all the Earth.

Thou teaching and ruling power of fle≈øh, thou ha≈øt had three periods of time, to vaunt thy ≈øelf over thy Brother; the fir≈øt was from the time of thy coming in, called A-dam, or a ≈øtop-age, till Mo≈øes came; and there thou that wa≈øt a ≈øelf-lover in Cain, killed thy brother Abel, a plain-hearted man that loved righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe: And thou by thy wi≈ødom and bea≈øtly government, made the whole Earth to ≈øtinck, till Noah came, which was a time of the world, like the coming in of the watery Seed into the womb, towards the bringing forth of the man child.

And from Noah till Mo≈øes came, thou ≈øtill ha≈øt ruled in vaunting, pride, and cruel oppre≈ø≈øion; I≈øhmael again≈øt I≈øaac,
E≈øau again≈øt Iacob; for thou ha≈øt ≈øtill been the man of fle≈øh that hath ever per≈øecuted the man of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, the Spirit Rea≈øon.

And Secondly, From Mo≈øes till the Son of Man came, which was a time of the world, that the man child could not ≈øpeak like a man, but li≈øping, making ≈øigns to ≈øhew his meaning; as we ≈øee many Creatures that cannot ≈øpeak do. For Mo≈øes Law was a Language lapped up in Types, Sacrifices, Forms, and Cu≈øtoms, which was a weak time. And in this time likewi≈øe, O thou teaching and ruling power, thou wa≈øt an oppre≈ø≈øor; for look into Scriptures and ≈øee if Aaron and the Prie≈øts were not the fir≈øt that deceived the people; and the Rulers, as Kings and Governors, were continually the Ocean-head, out of who≈øe power, Burdens, Oppre≈ø≈øions, and Poverty did flow out upon the Earth: and the≈øe two Powers ≈øtill hath been the Cur≈øe, that hath led the Earth, mankind, into confu≈øion and death by their imaginary and ≈øelvi≈øh teaching and ruling, and it could be no otherwi≈øe; for while man looks upon him≈øelf, as an imperfect Creation, and ≈øeeks and runs abroad for a teacher and a ruler, he is all this time a ≈øtranger to the Spirit that is within him≈øelf.

But though the Earth hath been generally thus in darkne≈ø≈øe, ≈øince the A-dam ri≈øe up, and hath owned a Light, and a Law without them to walk by, yet ≈øome have been found as watchmen, in this night time of the world, that have been taught by the Spirit within them, and not by any fle≈øh without them, as Abraham, I≈øaac, Iacob, and the Prophets: And the≈øe, and ≈øuch as the≈øe, have ≈øtill been the Butt, at whom, the powers of the Earth in all ages of the world, by their ≈øelvi≈øh Laws, have ≈øhot their fury.

And then Thirdly from the time of the Son of man, which was a time that the man-child began to ≈øpeak like a child growing upward to manhood, till now, that the Spirit is ri≈øing up in ≈øtrength. O thou teaching and ruling power of the earthy man, thou ha≈øt been an oppre≈ø≈øor, by impri≈øonment, impoveri≈øhing, and martyrdom; and all thy power and wit, hath been to make Laws, and execute them again≈øt ≈øuch as ≈øtand for univer≈øal Liberty, which is the ri≈øing up of Iacob; as by tho≈øe ancient en≈ølaving Laws not yet blotted out, but held up as weapons again≈øt the man-child.

O thou Powers of England, though thou ha≈øt promi≈øed to make this People a Free People, yet thou ha≈øt ≈øo handled the matter, through thy ≈øelf-≈øeeking humour, That thou ha≈øt wrapped us up more in bondage, and oppre≈ø≈øion lies heavier upon us; not only bringing thy fellow Creatures, the Commoners, to a mor≈øel of Bread, but by confounding all ≈øorts of people by thy Government, of doing and undoing.

Fir≈øt, Thou ha≈øt made the people to take a Covenant and Oaths to endeavour a Reformation, and to bring in Liberty every man in his place; and yet while a man is in pur≈øuing of that Covenant, he is impri≈øoned and oppre≈ø≈øed by thy Officers, Courts, and Ju≈øtices, ≈øo called.

And all this, Becau≈øe they ≈øtand to maintain an univer≈øal Liberty and Freedom, which not only is our Birthright, which our Maker gave us, but which thou ha≈øt promi≈øed to re≈øtore unto us, from under the former oppre≈ø≈øing Powers that are gone before, and which likewi≈øe we have bought with our Money, in Taxes, Free-quarter, and Bloud-≈øhed; all which Sums thou ha≈øt received at our hands, and yet thou ha≈øt not given us our bargain.

O thou A-dam, thou E≈øau, thou Cain, thou Hypocritical man of fle≈øh, when wilt thou cea≈øe to kill thy yonger Brother? Surely thou mu≈øt not do this great Work of advancing the Creation out of Bondage; for thou art lo≈øt extremely, and drowned in the Sea of Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, Pride, and hardne≈øs of heart. The ble≈ø≈øing ≈øhall ri≈øe out of the du≈øt which thou treade≈øt under foot, Even the poor de≈øpi≈øed People, and they ≈øhall hold up
